Maximum penalty (Î»maxsubscriptğœ†\lambda_{\max}) 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3} 5â‹…10âˆ’3â‹…5superscript1035\cdot 10^{-3}
references:
Configurations: Table II details our configurations. For PruneFL, FedDST, and PruneTrain, we experimentally determined the optimal reconfiguration intervals Rğ‘…R to be 202020, 202020, and 111, respectively, to ensure the best possible model performance; the same for step size Qğ‘„Q for all models. Especially, the annealing factor for FedDST is set as 0.50.50.5.
As SNIP prunes the model before training, the global mask is pruned via one-shot achieving the target sparsity spsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘s_{p}. We used grid-search to fix the penalty factor for PruneTrain ranging from 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} to 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5} for different experiments. When necessary, other hyperparameters were set to match ours. In non-i.i.d. case, the penalty for the proximal term in FedProx is determined via grid-search ranging from 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} to 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5}. FedDIP+Prox adopts the optimal combination of penalty values for FedDIP and FedProx.

Model LeNet;sp=.9subscriptğ‘ ğ‘.9s_{p}=.9 AlexNet;sp=.9subscriptğ‘ ğ‘.9s_{p}=.9 ResNet;sp=.8subscriptğ‘ ğ‘.8s_{p}=.8
FedAvg 89.50 (.09) 85.07 (.13) 70.92 (.10)
FedDP 88.06 (.08) 84.81 (.18) 69.23 (.14)
FedDIP 88.26 (0.09) 85.14 (.22) 69.67 (.10)
PruneFL 86.00 (.10) 81.64 (.17) 68.17 (.20)
SNIP 86.08 (.15) 80.10 (.15) 51.46 (.11)
PruneTrain 84.36 (.10) 79.73 (.10) 69.39 (.08)

# param.(FedAvg) 62K 23.3M 11.2M
# param.(pruned) 6.1K 2.3M 2.2M
1 Mean accuracy; standard deviation in â€˜()â€™.
references:
Figures 2(a), 3(a), and 4(a) demonstrate that FedDIP surpasses other baselines in achieving the highest top-1 accuracy (ratio of the correctly classified images) while maintaining the same extreme target sparsity.
As indicated in Table III, to attain target sparsity of sp=0.9subscriptğ‘ ğ‘0.9s_{p}=0.9 and sp=0.8subscriptğ‘ ğ‘0.8s_{p}=0.8 respectively, FedDIP only compromises LeNet-5 and ResNet-18 model accuracy by 1.24%percent1.241.24\% and 1.25%percent1.251.25\%, respectively.
For AlexNet, FedDIP can even improve model performance 0.7%percent0.70.7\%, compared with FedAvg with sp=0.9subscriptğ‘ ğ‘0.9s_{p}=0.9.

To make a fair comparison of cumulative communication cost during training (amount of information exchanged in MB)
w.r.t. a fixed budget, we showcase the relationship between communication cost and accuracy.
Figures 2(b), 3(b), 4(b), and specifically
Table IV present a comprehensive overview, emphasizing that FedDIP, when provided with adequate communication cost (budget),
effectively prunes the model across all experiments outperforming the other models. This indicates the trade-off between model performance and communication/training cost.
FedDIP demonstrates comparable communication efficiency to other baselines, principally due to the minimal decrement in model performance. Through our experiments, it is evidenced that FedDIP achieves optimally pruned models under
conditions of extreme sparsity, while incurring less or equivalent communication costs compared to FedAvg.
Even in the early stages (i.e., in restricted budget cases), FedDIP manages to match the communication efficiency of other pruning methods in the CIFAR experiments. This underscores the capacity of our approach to effectively balance model performance and communication expenditure. All in all, FedDIP introduces
only minor computational overhead due to the incremental regularization, while achieving high accuracy compared to baselines. This computational requirement is on par with that of PruneTrain, PruneFL, and SNIP, given the same sparsity at each epoch. A slight increase in computational cost can be justified by the improvements achieved in the final model performance considering extremely high sparsity. The size of the pruned CNN models (Table III) has been significantly reduced (âˆ¼similar-to\sim 1 order of magnitude) from the un-pruned models in FedAvg.

S6.T5.caption: Table V: Extension to non-i.i.d. data
S6.T5.table:
Model Performance1 (%percent\%) (non-i.i.d. case)
Case LeNet-5 AlexNet ResNet-18
FedAvg 76.42(0.28) 61.59 (0.73) 16.44 (0.49)
FedProx 76.63(0.34) 65.74 (0.26) 18.48 (0.91)
FedDIP+Prox 74.49 (0.09) 60.47 (0.52) 19.22 (0.8)
1 Mean of the highest five top-1 test accuracy during Tğ‘‡T rounds.
references: As shown in Table V, our methodology exhibits strong adaptability to FedProx (non-pruning), yielding commendable results on non-i.i.d. data. When juxtaposed with FedAvg, our approach manages to maintain comparable results even after pruning 90%percent9090\% of model parameters, albeit at a slight trade-off of 1-2% in model accuracy in the experiments with LeNet-5 and AlexNet. Across a span of T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000 rounds, FedDIP emerges as the superior performer in terms of top-1 accuracy, particularly at sparsity sp=0.8subscriptğ‘ ğ‘0.8s_{p}=0.8 in ResNet-18. This comprehensive suite of results underscores the adaptability of FedDIP in effectively managing non-i.i.d. cases, even in extreme sparsity.
